When I wash a car I like to keep the car wet, and myself dry. Call me odd, but that's the way I like it. What I like, and what a kindergartener named Superman likes are very different programs. As you know, we have a newer car. I've been looking forward to cleaning it all week. Finally, Saturday morning comes. I met with a client, then I'm off to clean the car. I started with the inside. I wanted it to feel brand new. I'm scrubbing, cleaning, wiping... you know the drill. I get done with the passenger side and move to the driver side and notice there are 2 little boys (kindergarten) hanging out in the carport next to me. They are playing with the hose. Awe, how cute. Cute until I became a target that is. Most of you know I like to have a good time and horse around. This time was a little different. Not because my goal of cleaning the car was thrown off track by 2 cute kindergarten boys. It was different because I didn't know if washing a car and getting into a water fight with 2 kids is legal! So, after declaring a quick loss in the water fight (and realizing my car was NOT going to get clean today) I got the heck out of there. Yeah I know, I'm a little paranoid. Had it been kids I knew, we would have had a BLAST. So, I left the kids feeling victorious, and came home feeling ticked at all the social sponges out there that make this world less fun that it needs to be. What a mess. Someday it will all be different. I'm looking forward to that each day I get older.

If you have been reading Amelia's " urlLink point of contact " you know that we have a urlLink newer car . Sometimes I wonder if at the core of a car's existence is the need to challenge my faith. If you have ever had car trouble, you know just what I'm talking about. Because a car is so practical, when it breaks down I wonder how God could have overlooked the situation. I complain to God. What did I ever do to deserve this? You know I’m trying to save for a house. This isn’t fair! The car seems light when compared to other people’s burdens. I know. I understand that. That’s a lesson most of us learn in Sunday school. However, that’s much different than the lesson I’m relearning this time around. What’s been most revealing through this situation is that I have replaced faith with my own sinful griping. My gripes assume one thing: God isn’t watching over me. I know that assumption is full of holes, BUT it takes the weight off of my shoulders to have faith. Faith requires me to look beyond the situation and still see a faithful God. Maybe that’s why they call it faith. So, two weeks ago I started looking through the black smoke rolling out of the Concorde and began looking for the faithful God I knew was there all along. He was just around the corner waiting with a 2002 Lancer that Amelia and I affectionately call “God’s Car”.

I didn’t realize anyone knew about “What’s the PO!NT?” or even read it until the last post. I had several people e-mail me with notes of concern. I was surprised. As a result, I didn’t post the past few days. It’s been a consuming thought, and didn’t feel people would want to wade through emotions. These types of situations have a way of shedding light on our views of God. We all-of-a-sudden have to make the situation fit within our view of who He is. Sometimes it doesn’t work. Sometimes our view of Him changes. Sometimes that a good thing.

Doug Monahan, founder and chairman of Sunset Direct, recently received a rather exclusive award. However, just because it’s exclusive doesn’t mean you want it. The award was given by urlLink Business 2.0 as part of their annual “101 Dumbest Moments in Business” feature. Doug received the “Dumbest Moment in Human Resources" for issuing the following memo. "I expect my computers to be used for work only. I expect my phones to be used for work only. Should you receive a personal call, keep it short. Should you receive a personal e-mail, I expect the e-mail either not answered, or a brief note telling whoever is sending you e-mails at work to stop immediately. Should I go through machines, which I assure you, I will be doing, and I find anything to the contrary, you will be terminated immediately. For those who think I am kidding, and do not get with this program, I will promise you that by Christmas eve 8:00 you will be gone." I would assume that from his memo this guy isn’t familiar with Dale Carnegie or the book “ How to Win Friends and Influence People .” This type of behavior fuels my theory that there are more jerkwads in leadership then there are good people in leadership. Maybe I’m just cynical, or maybe there is a bit of truth in that thought. Never-the-less it’s been my experience that those that are loud, obnoxious, self-centered and object driven (as apposed to people driven) seem to make their way up the corporate ladder faster than the truly genuine leader. It’s been a sour pill to swallow, but an eye opening one as well. I want to believe that someday these tyrant leaders will get their just rewards. However, that would require Business 2.0 to increase the recipients from 101 to 1000001. Meanwhile I’ll try not to get caught up in handing out judgment and having pity parties.

urlLink Amelia and I hit the pavement for a 2 mile walk when I get home from work most nights of the week. This is our time to connect. We chat hand in hand about life, goals, owning a house someday, kids, faith, business, culture... the list goes on. Needless to say it's the highlight of my day. One of our most talked about subjects is faith . Not faith as in; what religion we subscribe to. We know where we stand with that one. Instead, we talk about the kind of faith that moves us through the day. You know, things like: I felt forgotten today. Did He forget, or did I lose focus? In fact, that was our most recent conversation. I came home from work in a rare mood where I felt like God was ignoring me. O.K. I'll confess, the mood is not as rare as I'd like it to be. We have been trying to save money and do some things for some people we love. Just when we get things headed in the right direction our car starts having trouble. I felt forgotten. Amelia greeted me at the door. I quick change clothes and we hit the pavement. She soon began to tell me about her day and what she was dealing with. It came up that she was feeling the same thing that morning. She, on the other hand, handled it much better than I. This is one of those times when I just shut-up and listen. She began to tell me how she started listing all the things she was grateful for. Things like good friends and roof over our head. It didn't take long to realize I had lost my focus. She then recounted all the times in our past where we felt like God had forgotten, and in hindsight He was with us every stumble, trip and fall of the way. I needed those reminders. It was one of those times where God heard my moaning and sent and angel to set my focus back on Him.
Joining the ranks.

I want to give a shout out to my big sis. Hey girl, I love ya big time. Hang in there! Also, a quick welcome to CRobertson. Welcome buddy. So, I’ve been thinking. (practicing what I preach) More like I’ve been observing, and then thinking. I think that might be good way to go about it. Here’s the scoop. This guy goes on a family vacation along with his in-laws. Everything is great until he butts heads with his mother-in-law over a minuet detail. He explodes. They get in a fight. Everything is ugly. However, being the good Christian he is, he apologizes. They fix things up, and vacation is back to beaches and sunshine. As he recalls the story and sends up a “praise God” I can’t help but wonder how many people use God as an escape-goat for allowing their tempers to fly (among other things). Now your saying to yourself: “Isn’t that the way it should work? Aren’t we supposed to go back and ask our brothers forgiveness if we hurt them?” Yes, that is the way it should work. (pause) However, I’m watching people emotionally assassinate others over and over again, and rebound 20 minutes later with an apology. They operate from the belief that when they apologize, the other person is bound, required and obligated to forgive them, allowing them to go back to enjoying the beach and catching rays. Doesn’t that bother anyone? It should! These people are using scripture as a safe place to hurt people. Their apology has become a tool to manipulate people into letting their sin be swept under the carpet and their own childish temper to go un-dealt with. For them, it’s easier to go back and ask forgiveness that it is to control their temper. Besides, once they ask for forgiveness, it’s up to the forgiver to deal with it right? They think they have shifted the burden back to the offended. Now, don’t get me wrong. I’m all about the forgiveness process. God has it in place for a reason. However, that reason doesn’t include manipulating people. The forgiveness process is about having a change of heart. It’s about rebuilding what was destroyed. It’s not about checkmarks and bourdon shifting. Caught up in that cycle? Get some help. Tired of being manipulated? Challenge the offender and reestablish boundaries. You don’t have to be a victim of spiritual manipulation. That's my PO!NT for today. urlLink “What shall we say then? Should we continue in sin that grace may increase? May it never be!”

I received several comments today on yesterday’s blog. It appears that I have hit both a cord and a nerve with one foul swoop of the pen (or keyboard, as the case may be). My PO!NT for being on a blog is to share and develop my thoughts. I don’t do much day-to-day recaps. urlLink I’ll leave that to the pro! I’m here to flush out my thoughts, and force myself to wade through the process of finishing one. (I know some of you find that hard to believe.) It’s a healthy process, and one that I find challenging. I’m currently working on a blog entry that I started back in November. If you notice, I didn’t have a blog back in November. Actually, it’s the “thought” I was wading through that challenged me to find a way to flush it out and share it. Hence the blog. I’m convinced that most people don’t do enough thought thinking. I know that sounds odd, but follow me on this one. Most people go day-in-and-day-out without finding something new to think about. Each day brings along it’s own set of concerns and priorities, and we focus on managing the affect they have on our life. That’s life. That’s what we do. I think we need to take our thinking one step further. We need to find a new thought to think about, to sort out and figure out. Our minds need the stimulation. I hope you're getting what I’m saying, and not getting what I’m not saying. I’m not saying we need to carve out hours in our day to philosophize over odd scenario and what-ifs. What I am saying is that we need to recognize new thoughts, and see where they go. I’m also not saying they have to be deep thoughts, or even interesting thoughts. Sometimes you don’t know what kind of thought it will be until you wade through it. There is no harm in wading through a thought, only to come to the conclusion that it was a boring thought. It’s the exercise that counts. I hope that gets you thinking, and that’s my PO!NT.

I have too many friends that are afraid to stand up for a political party. Some of them can't because they are in ministry. I don't think they are allowed to endorse anyone. It's something about church and state. I don't know all the details. The ones that are not in ministry are the ones I'm getting concerned about. I can't tell if they just don't care who runs the country, or they are trying to be politically correct about politics! Here is what I see going on. Too many "Christians" are using God as an excuse to sit on the sidelines. They quote verses about how God appoints leadership. They also use "relevancy" as their excuse. They think by not saying anything at all, they are avoiding a conflict that could somehow turn people off to Christ. "You can't have that kind of conflict and be relevant in today’s culture." or "If you tick them off politically, you'll never win them spiritually." Here is my thought: YOU will NEVER win them spiritually. That part is NOT up to you! Besides, if you want to influence someone, you have to have an end in mind. That means you have to have a value that you are pressing towards. Influence involves a reaction. A reaction involves an energy that must be dealt with. The next big group I see is one that votes based on a financial agenda. They have ideals as to where they think money should go. Good ideals I'm sure. They want to see more funding to help the poor, aids patients, homeless and other charity groups. I guess I can see how those could be noble agendas. So, they vote for the party they think will help bring that kind of humanitarian work. Here is my thought: If you call yourself a Christ follower, you won't depend on the government to do humanitarian work for you. You will get your hands dirty, and do it yourself! Why? Because that's what Christ did! He didn't expect the Roman government to feed the hungry or tend to the sick. He did it, and then commanded us to do it! That group may have noble intentions, it’s the trade off is what concerns me. If you vote for "the little man" party, you may get your humanitarian efforts, but you loose a LOT of moral virtues that Christ followers hold dear. You know, things like valuing the life of an unborn child and the sanctity of marriage between a man and a woman (the way God designed it). Here is my thought: Since when did a financial agenda become more important that the fundamentals of our faith? There are plenty of financial pillars within the Christian faith that should be valued and adopted, but when did money become more important than human life? Why would you vote for someone that doesn’t value the same basics that you do? Is your financial agenda more important than that? WOW, I hope not. Now, I’m not so naive as to think that George W. is perfect. I know there are things we all would like to see changed. What I’m trying to say is that I think we, as a church, need to engage others about politics. We, collectively, and individually have a lot of influence, and it’s O.K. to use that influence in politics. My prayer between now and November's election will be that those who call themselves Christ followers will voice their beliefs. Stand for them. Share them. Vote for them. I will not hope for tomorrow good things, while today sowing no good seed. That’s my PO!NT.

I guess you could label me as a reader. I always have a book or 3 in process. (I keep several going because I get bored easily.) I wouldn’t call myself a fast reader, like . urlLink Ameliou , who read an entire novel today. However, I do enjoy a good book. Most of my reading is on leadership and business related material. As a result of reading several John Maxwell books I have subscribed to urlLink Maximum Impact Club . The club is a monthly CD subscription hosted and taught by Dr. Maxwell. The CD arrives in a nice jacket along with a fill-in-the-blank workbook to follow along with. I often have one of his CD’s playing in the car as I go about my day. Yesterday’s lesson was about going from ordinary to extraordinary. It’s a CD that I have listened to a few times before, but this time I caught a concept I didn’t quite connect with. He made the claim that “people do what people see .” I know you have heard that saying before, maybe rephrased like “monkey see, monkey do.” It does ring with a bit of truth, but I think the issue is much deeper than this old cliché. Fundamentally it’s a way to pass the blame for our actions onto others. How many times have you heard; “But Joey uses those kinds of words.” Or “But dad watches that TV show.” I understand that you have to model the actions you want instilled in people, but that’s not the heart of the issue. Here’s my PO!NT: People do what people value . Example: If you want your employee to be on-time, than teach them to value punctuality. You can, and should, teach values through your action. However, it’s more than just “Do as I do.” Those are famous last words. How many times have we all been caught doing the very thing we don’t want others doing? If your actions are your only point of reference for right and wrong than you’re in deep weeds, and so are those emulating your actions. Actions can be misinterpreted, and downright wrong. Actions need to be an out-growth of values. That should stir up a few questions. Questions like: What are my values? How do I live out my values? Where have I been expecting performance where values need changed? Where are my actions not connecting with my values? What does God value, and how do my values need to be realigned? I know these can be frustrating questions. That’s the PO!NT. These are questions I ask myself on a regular basis. Why? Because I want my life and actions to be value driven. My value system puts meaning into my actions, and establishes boundaries for everyday-living. I also know I don’t have everything aligned correctly. It’s a process I have to work on daily. So, here is my PO!NT 42day: Monkey do what monkey value.

It was fall, almost four years ago, when Amelia and I found ourselves in a 12 week intensive urlLink Bible study on what God has to say about finances. This study consisted of people from all walks of life and all points in their journey with Christ. It wasn’t a group of people you would imagine having an espresso together or catching a baseball game on the weekend with one another. We were all very different, and we knew it. We met in the private school house of a multimillionaire from 7-9pm each Thursday. Things started promptly at 7 with the group in a circle on their knees in prayer. Each week, each member of the group was responsible for 2 things; memorizing the pre-assigned passage of scripture, and having completed the previous week’s homework. If a member failed to complete one of the two assignments, they were not allowed to participate in the group discussion. Once we had gone through the study and reviewed the following weeks’ assignments we would exchange prayer requests, and once again, gather in a circle on our knees in prayer. This was an amazing 3 months. The group was honest, caring and insightful. By the end of that study we were a true community. It’s been 4 years since Amelia and I have been in a group like that. (We co-lead that same study once again the following spring. It was equally as impacting, maybe even more so.) Don’t get me wrong, God has collided us with individuals and couples that we have shared true community with, but nothing in the form of a “small group” since. This is what I think made those groups work. Expectation for growth. Expectation for knowing and studying God’s word. Expectation for prayer. Expectation for participation. It sounds rough, rigid and almost scary doesn’t it? Well who said true community was easy? There is a price to pay for everything worth having.
